bedding.name: Fuchsia 'Lena', trailing hardy fuchsia
bedding.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
bedding.care: Garden care: To encourage growth, pinch out the growing tips of young plants after the sixth or seventh pair of leaves.  During the growing season water regularly, applying a balanced liquid fertiliser each month. Cut back to the permanent framework in early spring. Protect the roots with a generous layer of mulch in autumn, or move potted plants to a sheltered position in the garden during the worst of the winter weather.

bedding.name: Fuchsia 'Sophia'
bedding.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
bedding.soil: Soil: moderately fertile, humus-rich, well-drained soil
bedding.growth: Rate of growth: average to fast-growing

bedding.name: Fuchsia 'Delta's Sara'

bedding.name: Pelargonium 'Tip Top Duet'
bedding.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
bedding.care: Garden care: Pot up your pelargoniums, but only place them outside in the garden after the risk of frost has passed. Remove the spent   flowers as they fade, and keep them well fed using a dilute solution of a  high-potash liquid fertiliser (Tomorite is ideal) at regular intervals. If you  want to keep them over the winter, move them to a frost free environment and avoid overwatering during the colder months.

bedding.name: Lathyrus odoratus 'Matucana', sweet pea
bedding.growth: Rate of growth: average to fast-growing
bedding.care: Garden care: Incorporate lots of well-rotted organic matter in the planting hole. Feed with a high potash fertiliser such as Tomorite to encourage plenty of flowers  and keep cutting them so that you get plenty more!

bedding.name: Euphorbia hypericifolia Diamond Frost 'Inneuphe'
bedding.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
bedding.growth: Rate of growth: average to fast-growing

bedding.name: Thunbergia alata 'Suzie Orange with Eye'
bedding.soil: Soil:  fertile, moist but well drained
bedding.care: Garden care: Keep under glass where temperatures dip below  5C, only moving outside after the frosts have passed.   A twining climber, it will need support, and it should be watered freely when in growth - and apply a balanced liquid fertiliser monthly.

bedding.name: Visnaga daucoides, bishop's weed

bedding.care: Garden care:Ammis may need staking - particularly in more  exposed positions. Avoid cutting back some of the flowers before they have  had a chance to set seed if you want to sow them for the following year.

bedding.position: Position:  full sun or partial shade
bedding.care: Garden care: In autumn group container-grown plants close to a warm house wall, ensuring that containers are raised off the ground using pot feet.

bedding.name: Osteospermum 'Sunny Mary', African daisy

bedding.growth: Rate of growth: average to fast-growing
bedding.care:
Garden care: Provide cloche protection where frosts are very severe or prolonged.

Please note that these wallflowers should be planted out as soon as they arrive!

bedding.name: Chrysanthemum 'Jasoda Pink'
bedding.flowering: Flowering period:  August to the first frosts
bedding.care:
Hardiness: tender perennial, but usually treated as an annual

This is an instant impact plant, which will give your borders and pots a bold splash of colour, that will last well into the autumn. A new form, it has a dense, branching habit, but its the lashings of pink daisies that are the star attraction. 

  These are large, garden ready plants already approx 40cm tall  (including the pot), and they will be sent out with flowers already forming,   so are perfect for creating instant impact.

bedding.name: Helianthus annuus 'Sunsation Yellow', sunflower
bedding.soil: Soil:  moderately fertile, humus-rich, moist but well-drained, neutral to alkaline soil
bedding.care: Garden care: Pot up or plant out into a sunny spot and  keep well watered during the warm weather. Feed with a high potash  fertiliser (Tomorite is ideal) and   deadhead the spent flowers as they fade.

bedding.name: Dianthus  Green Trick, pink
bedding.care: Garden care: Incorporate lots of well-rotted manure or garden compost into the planting hole. Apply a balanced fertiliser in spring and deadhead to prolong flowering.

bedding.name: Pelargonium  Mosquitaway Lizzy
bedding.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
bedding.care: Garden care: Place them outside in the garden after the risk of frost has passed. If you  want to keep them over the winter, move them to a frost free environment and avoid overwatering during the colder months.

bedding.name: Cyclamen persicum Verano Red, cyclamen
bedding.position: Position:  full sun to partial shade
bedding.care: Garden care:  These half hardy annual will need protection from  frosts so place them in a sheltered spot or where you can cover them with a frost fleece. Deadheading will prolonge flowering.

bedding.name: Papaver dubium subsp. lecoqiiBeth's poppy
bedding.care: Garden care: If you do not want them to set seed, then you should remove the spent flowers as they fade.

bedding.name: 'Royal Mosaic', trailing hardy fuchsia
bedding.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
bedding.care: Garden care: To encourage growth, pinch out the growing tips of young plants after the sixth or seventh pair of leaves.  During the growing season water regularly, applying a balanced liquid fertiliser each month. Cut back to the permanent framework in early spring. Protect the roots with a generous layer of mulch in autumn, or move potted plants to a sheltered position in the garden during the worst of the winter weather.

bedding.name: Anagallis monellii 'Skylover', blue pimpernell
bedding.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
bedding.care: Garden care: Keep the soil or compost moist by watering regularly during dry spells and feed with a balanced fertiliser every fourteen days.  Take care not to overwater in the early stages. Although usually grown as an annual in this country, plants that are protected with a dry mulch may survive mild winters where temperatures only occasionally fall below 6 to 8�C (42 to 46�F)

bedding.name: Ammi majus, bishop's weed
bedding.position: Position:  full sun or partial shade

bedding.care: Garden care: It may need staking - particularly in more  exposed positions. Avoid cutting back some of the flowers before they have  had a chance to set seed if you want to sow them for the following year.

bedding.name: Orlaya grandiflora, white laceflower
bedding.care: Garden care:  Feed with a liquid fertiliser every two weeks when it is actively growing. Once the plant has finished flowering you can collect the seed and sow immediately to propagate more plants for the following year.

Garden care: Provide cloche protection where frosts are very severe or prolonged.

bedding.name: Ipomoea lobata, Spanish flag
bedding.care: Garden care: Make sure there is adequate support for it to  climb up, but do not plant it outside until all risk of frost has passed. Water freely when in growth and apply a liquid fertiliser at   monthly intervals. If it is not going to be overwintered in a warm place,  cut it back to ground level after it is hit by a frost and start again  with a new plant the following spring.

bedding.name: Chrysanthemum 'Jasoda Mauve'
bedding.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
bedding.flowering: Flowering period:  August to the first frosts
bedding.care:
Hardiness: hardy annual

This free-flowering chrysanthemum puts on an unbeatable display in  late summer and autumn when the foliage virtually disappears  beneath a sea of flowers. Perfect for pots or borders,  they will add a much needed blast of colour when many other plants are well past their best. 

  These are large garden ready plants already approx 40cm tall in pot and are sent out with flowers forming all ready to be planted out and create instant impact.

bedding.name: Ipomoea purpurea 'Star of Yelta', morning glory

Water freely when in growth and apply a liquid fertiliser at   monthly intervals. If it is not going to be overwintered in a warm place,  cut it back to ground level after it is hit by a frost and start again  with a new plant the following spring.

bedding.care: Garden care: Cut back to just above ground level in autumn. A generous self-seeder if happy in its spot, it will soon form a generous  swathe. For this reason, it is currently illegal to plant, or cause it to grow, in the wild.

bedding.name: Argyranthemum frutescens, white marguerite standard
bedding.soil: Soil: well drained, moderately fertile soil
bedding.care:
Hardiness: tender

A tender evergreen shrub that will provide masses of colour from spring to early autumn. One of the best loved of all the summer bedding plants due to the long-lasting flowers, the pure white daisies with yellow centres look great above the rich green foliage. This standard shaped plant looks elegant in any setting, and can either be used to add height to a mixed border or pot it up and use it as a focal point. Like all marguerites, it needs a sunny spot for best results, and should be grown in a pot which can be protected during the winter in frost prone areas. The ceramic pot shown is not included, however, if you wish to pot  yours up, we do have a wide range of pots on our website to choose from.

bedding.growth:
Hardiness:  fully hardy

Hang this ivy ball in place of your hanging basket  during the winter months.  The red ribbon provides a festive entrance to visitors.
bedding.flowering: Garden care: Water well regularly during the growing season, providing a balanced liquid fertiliser each month. Keeping moist during the winter months. Plants may be pruned at any time of the year to keep the ball shape. Plants are  nestled in a hanging basket in the bottom of the ball so they are really easy to water.

bedding.name: Fuchsia 'Swingtime', trailing fuchsia
bedding.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
bedding.care: Garden care: To encourage growth, pinch out the growing tips of young plants after the sixth or seventh pair of leaves.  During the growing season water regularly, applying a balanced liquid fertiliser each month. Cut back to the permanent framework in early spring. Protect the roots with a generous layer of mulch in autumn, or move potted plants to a sheltered position in the garden during the worst of the winter weather.

bedding.name: Lathyrus odoratus 'Charlie's Angel', spencer sweet pea
bedding.growth: Rate of growth: average to fast-growing
bedding.care: Garden care: Incorporate lots of well-rotted organic matter in the planting hole. Feed with a high potash fertiliser, such as Tomorite for plenty of flowers and keep cutting them so that you get plenty more!

bedding.name: Fuchsia 'Evita', fuchsia
bedding.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
bedding.soil: Soil: moderately fertile, humus-rich, well-drained soil
bedding.growth: Rate of growth: average to fast-growing
bedding.flowering: Flowering period: May to the first frosts
bedding.care: Garden care: To encourage growth, pinch out the growing tips of young plants after the sixth or seventh pair of leaves.  During the growing season water regularly, applying a balanced liquid fertiliser each month.

bedding.name: Lunaria annua 'Chedglow', honesty
bedding.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
bedding.soil: Soil: fertile, moist but well-drained soil
bedding.care: Garden care  It may need staking - particularly in more exposed positions.

bedding.name: Chrysanthemum 'Jasoda Yellow'
bedding.flowering: Flowering period:  August to the first frosts
bedding.care:
Hardiness: tender perennial, but usually treated as an annual

This new chrysanthemum has a compact habit, and forms a natural  dome shaped bush of foliage, that is practically smothered with  yellow flowers from late summer to the first frosts. Ideal for pots and borders, they will give you a bright splash of colour, long after many other plants are well past their best.

bedding.name: Campanula portenschlagiana Ambella Intens Purple, dalmatian bellflower
bedding.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
bedding.care: Garden care: Protect the foliage from slug damage using environmentally friendly slug pellets or beer traps. During the growing season water freely.

bedding.name: Fuchsia 'Celia Smedley'
bedding.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
bedding.soil: Soil: moderately fertile, humus-rich, well-drained soil
bedding.growth: Rate of growth: average to fast-growing
bedding.flowering: Flowering period: May to the first frosts
bedding.care: Garden care: To encourage growth, pinch out the growing tips of young plants after the sixth or seventh pair of leaves.  During the growing season water regularly, applying a balanced liquid fertiliser each month. Cut back to the permanent framework in early spring. Protect the roots with a generous layer of mulch in autumn, or move potted plants to a sheltered position in the garden during the worst of the winter weather.

bedding.name: Osteospermum, African daisy Blueberry Shake
bedding.care: Garden care: Avoid winter wet and protect plants in very cold areas.  Semi-ripe cuttings can be taken in late summer and over-wintered in a  frost-free place.

bedding.name: Nemesia 'Wisley Vanilla'
bedding.care: Garden care: Keep plants well watered throughout the summer to maintain flower production. Protect plants in winter

bedding.name: Lathyrus 'Linda C', sweet pea
bedding.growth: Rate of growth: average to fast-growing
bedding.care: Garden care: Incorporate lots of well-rotted organic matter in the planting hole. Feed with a high potash fertiliser, such as Tomorite for plenty of flowers and keep cutting them so that you get plenty more!

bedding.name: Cyclamen persicum Winfall White, cyclamen
bedding.position: Position:  full sun to partial shade
bedding.care: Garden care:  These half hardy annual will need protection from  frosts so place them in a sheltered spot or where you can cover them with a frost fleece. Deadheading will prolonge flowering.

bedding.name: Chrysanthemum 'Jasoda Dark Orange', pot mum
bedding.flowering: Flowering period:  August to the first frosts
bedding.care:
Hardiness: tender perennial, but usually treated as an annual

Naturally dome-shaped and smothered in flowers, these plants are ready  to be planted straight out into patio pots or borders, where they will  offer fiery colour right up until the first frosts. 

  These are large, garden ready plants already approx 40cm tall  (including the pot), and they will be sent out with flowers already forming,   so are perfect for creating instant impact.

bedding.name: Thunbergia alata 'Arizona Dark Red', black-eyed Susan vine
bedding.soil: Soil:  fertile, moist, well drained or sandy
bedding.care: Garden care: Keep under glass where temperatures dip below  5C, only moving outside after the frosts have passed.   A twining climber, it will need support, and it should be watered freely when in growth - and apply a balanced liquid fertiliser monthly.

bedding.name: Thunbergia alata 'Sunny Suzy Brownie', black-eyed Susan vine
bedding.soil: Soil:  fertile, moist, well drained or sandy
bedding.care: Garden care: Keep under glass where temperatures dip below  5C, only moving outside after the frosts have passed.   A twining climber, it will need support, and it should be watered freely when in growth - and apply a balanced liquid fertiliser monthly.

bedding.name: Chrysanthemum 'Jasoda White', pot mum
bedding.flowering: Flowering period:  August to the first frosts
bedding.care:
Hardiness: tender perennial, but usually treated as an annual

Pop these into your pots or borders and give your garden an instant lift, which will last right up to the first frosts. These naturally domed  shaped plants are strong growers - and they will  produce an abundance of white daisies.

  These are large, garden ready plants already approx 40cm tall  (including the pot), and they will be sent out with flowers already forming,   so are perfect for creating instant impact.
